articles.headline: At Lehman, Chief Exudes Confidence
articles.snippet: Stepping into the spotlight for the first time since he replaced two senior executives less than a week ago, Richard S. Fuld Jr. offered a spirited defense of his stewardship of Lehman Brothers.
articles.abstract: Stepping into the spotlight for the first time since he replaced two senior executives less than a week ago, Richard S. Fuld Jr. offered a spirited defense of his stewardship of Lehman Brothers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Richard S. Fuld Jr., the chief executive of Lehman Brothers, offered a spirited defense of his stewardship of the embattled investment bank on Monday, saying he was confident that Lehman was sound even as the bank posted a second-quarter loss of $2.8 billion.

articles.headline: Latest Honda Runs on Hydrogen, Not Petroleum
articles.snippet: The world’s first hydrogen-powered fuel-cell vehicle for mass production was wheeled off a Honda assembly line in Japan.
articles.abstract: The world’s first hydrogen-powered fuel-cell vehicle for mass production was wheeled off a Honda assembly line in Japan.
articles.lead_paragraph: TAKANEZAWA, Japan  It looks like an ordinary family sedan, costs more to build than a Ferrari and may have just moved the world one step closer to a future free of petroleum.

articles.headline: Demand for Data Puts Engineers in Spotlight
articles.snippet: Engineers who run data centers are in high demand as the growth in such facilities struggles to keep up with the increasing demands of Internet-era computing.
articles.abstract: Engineers who run data centers are in high demand as the growth in such facilities struggles to keep up with the increasing demands of Internet-era computing.
articles.lead_paragraph: In Silicon Valley, the stars have long been charismatic marketing visionaries and cool-nerd software wizards. By contrast, mechanical engineers who design and run computer data centers were traditionally regarded as little more than blue-collar workers in the high-tech world.

articles.headline: Booming, China Faults U.S. Policy on the Economy
articles.snippet: Americans once scolded the Chinese on mismanaging their economy. But in recent weeks, the fingers have been wagging in the other direction.
articles.abstract: Americans once scolded the Chinese on mismanaging their economy. But in recent weeks, the fingers have been wagging in the other direction.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING  Not long ago, Chinese officials sat across conference tables from American officials and got an earful.

articles.headline: How Close McCain Is to Bush Depends on the Issue
articles.snippet: It is hard to categorize John McCain as doctrinaire, but he appears to have ceded some of his maverick reputation.
articles.abstract: It is hard to categorize John McCain as doctrinaire, but he appears to have ceded some of his maverick reputation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Democrats like to say that electing Senator John McCain would usher in the third term of George W. Bush, and they do not mean it as a compliment. The Republicans counter that calling the senator “McBush” is political spin and that Mr. McCain is his own man.

articles.headline: Big Penalty Set for Law Firm, but Not a Trial
articles.snippet: The law firm known as Milberg, once a scourge of corporate America, agreed to the settlement to avoid a criminal trial, ending a seven-year investigation.
articles.abstract: The law firm known as Milberg, once a scourge of corporate America, agreed to the settlement to avoid a criminal trial, ending a seven-year investigation.
articles.lead_paragraph: The best-known shareholder law firm in the country agreed on Monday to pay $75 million to dodge a criminal trial, ending a seven-year investigation that tarnished the profession’s image.

articles.headline: Old-Line Taliban Commander Is Face of Rising Afghan Threat
articles.snippet: An attack has revealed the way former mujahedeen leaders combine forces with foreign terrorist groups.
articles.abstract: An attack has revealed the way former mujahedeen leaders combine forces with foreign terrorist groups.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan  The attack was little reported at the time. A suicide bombing on March 3 killed two NATO soldiers and two Afghan civilians and wounded 19 others in an American military base.

articles.headline: At Lehman, a Reminder of Loss
articles.snippet: The chief executive of Lehman Brothers, Richard S. Fuld Jr., tried to move ahead after a $2.8 billion loss in the second quarter.
articles.abstract: The chief executive of Lehman Brothers, Richard S. Fuld Jr., tried to move ahead after a $2.8 billion loss in the second quarter.
articles.lead_paragraph: The chief executive of Lehman Brothers, Richard S. Fuld Jr., stepped up to the microphone on Monday morning.

articles.headline: Despite Irish Vote, the Euro Remains Strong
articles.snippet: Ireland’s rejection of a treaty important to the European Union may have rattled the bloc’s sense of political unity, but it didn’t seem to faze the euro.
articles.abstract: Ireland’s rejection of a treaty important to the European Union may have rattled the bloc’s sense of political unity, but it didn’t seem to faze the euro.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT  Ireland’s rejection of the Lisbon Treaty has plunged Europe into a familiar bout of hand-wringing about the future of its grand experiment in political and economic integration.

articles.headline: Grand Juries Become Latest Abortion Battlefield
articles.snippet: Under an 1887 statute, Kansans gathered signatures to demand that a grand jury investigate an abortion clinic.
articles.abstract: Under an 1887 statute, Kansans gathered signatures to demand that a grand jury investigate an abortion clinic.
articles.lead_paragraph: WICHITA, Kan.  Opponents of Dr. George Tiller and his clinic here, one of the nation’s few providers of late-term abortions, have tried many ways to stop him over three decades. They have held protests, lobbied lawmakers and complained persistently to state regulators and prosecutors. There have also been several acts of violence, including one in which Dr. Tiller was shot in both arms.

articles.headline: Chilling a Deal for Bud
articles.snippet: The family behind Anheuser-Busch, the maker of Budweiser, is working hard to reject a generous takeover offer from its rival InBev.
articles.abstract: The family behind Anheuser-Busch, the maker of Budweiser, is working hard to reject a generous takeover offer from its rival InBev.
